item.title: Tyler Robinson’s Lawyers Press to Remove Prosecutors From Kirk Murder Case
item.description: Mr. Robinson’s lawyers argue that the entire prosecution team has a conflict of interest because one prosecutor’s daughter was present when Charlie Kirk was killed.
item.dc:creator: Jack Healy
item.media:description: Chad Grunander, a deputy Utah County attorney, testifying during a hearing in the Fourth District Court in Provo, Utah, on Tuesday.

item.title: Judge releases Venezuelan men charged in ICE shooting in Minneapolis, with conditions.
item.dc:creator: Talya Minsberg
item.media:description: Federal agents near the scene where a man was shot by an agent in North Minneapolis last month.

item.title: Racial Debate Rattles Texas Democratic Primary for Senate
item.description: State Representative James Talarico used the word “mediocre” in connection with a former House member who is Black. The controversy has repercussions for a key contest.
item.dc:creator: J. David Goodman
item.media:credit: Jordan Vonderhaar for The New York Times
item.media:description: Texas State Representative James Talarico at a town hall in New Braunfels, Texas, last month.

item.title: Trump, Changing Course, Throws Harvard Deal Talks Into Chaos
item.description: In the latest example of his mercurial negotiating style, President Trump went from dropping his ask for a $200 million fine to demanding $1 billion from the university.
item.dc:creator: Michael C. Bender, Alan Blinder, Mark Arsenault and Michael S. Schmidt
item.media:credit: Sophie Park for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump appeared to once again threaten to cut off Harvard from future research funding, which is the lifeblood of major research universities.

item.title: Judge Appears Likely to Curtail Hegseth’s Power to Penalize Kelly for Video
item.description: Attorneys for Democratic Senator Mark Kelly argued that Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth was brazenly violating the separation of powers by seeking to punish a member of Congress for public statements.
item.dc:creator: Megan Mineiro
item.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
item.media:description: Senator Mark Kelly, Democrat of Arizona, outside of federal court in Washington on Tuesday after a hearing in his case against the Trump administration.

item.title: Trump Repeats Call to ‘Nationalize’ Elections, as White House Walks It Back
item.description: President Trump’s extraordinary comments were the latest iteration of his unsubstantiated claims that U.S. elections are rigged as Republicans face potentially big losses next year.
item.dc:creator: Erica L. Green, Michael Gold and Robert Jimison
item.media:credit: Nick Hagen for The New York Times
item.media:description: A sign directs voters in Dearborn, Mich., in November 2024.

item.title: Trump Scolds CNN’s Kaitlan Collins for ‘Not Smiling’
item.description: Testy remarks from a president who has frequently singled out female journalists for criticism and personal attacks.
item.dc:creator: Michael M. Grynbaum
item.media:description: CNN’s Kaitlan Collins, center, asks President Donald Trump a question in the Oval Office in November.

item.title: Renee Good’s Brothers Call on Congress to Rein In Immigration Crackdown
item.description: At a forum on Capitol Hill held by congressional Democrats, the brothers of the 37-year-old American citizen fatally shot by an ICE agent said immigration enforcement tactics must be dialed back.
item.dc:creator: Michael Gold
item.category: House Committee on Oversight and Government Reform
item.media:credit: Tierney L. Cross/The New York Times
item.media:description: Brothers of Renee Good, Luke Ganger, left, and Brent Ganger, during a public forum at the Capitol in Washington on Tuesday.

item.title: Trump Releases Latest Rendering of White House Ballroom Project
item.description: President Trump emphasized that the ballroom would not be taller than the Executive Mansion of the White House, as he faces criticism over the size of the project.
item.dc:creator: Luke Broadwater
item.media:description: A rendering released by President Trump shows the latest design for a large ballroom on White House grounds.

item.title: Westminster Presbyterian Church in Minneapolis Is a Place for Protest
item.description: In the weeks since ICE agents began conducting operations across the city, Westminster Presbyterian has given its members a place to protest on their own terms.
item.dc:creator: Claire Fahy
item.media:credit: Jamie Kelter Davis for The New York Times
item.media:description: Westminster Presbyterian Church in Minneapolis on Monday. It was founded in 1857 and has found purpose in its city’s crisis.

item.title: Court Orders New Trial for Former U.C.L.A. Gynecologist James Heaps
item.description: James M. Heaps was sentenced to 11 years in prison in April 2023. A note from the jury to the judge during deliberations was never disclosed, and an appeals court said the case must be retried.
item.dc:creator: Michael Levenson
item.media:description: James Heaps, center, with his wife Deborah, left, and his lawyer Tracy Green, leaving court, in Los Angeles in 2019.

item.title: Colombians Rally During Their President’s Meeting with Trump
item.description: President Gustavo Petro had asked Colombians to gather around the country during his meeting with President Trump on Tuesday.
item.dc:creator: Annie Correal and Jorge Valencia
item.media:description: A rally in Bogotá, convened by the Colombian government, shows supporters of President Gustavo Petro during his visit to Washington.

item.title: U.S. Fighter Jet Shoots Down Iranian Drone Amid Heightened Tensions
item.description: A U.S. fighter jet shot down the Iranian drone after it “unnecessarily maneuvered” toward the Abraham Lincoln aircraft carrier.
item.dc:creator: Greg Jaffe
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: F/A-18 fighter jets parked on the flight deck of the aircraft carrier Abraham Lincoln in 2024.

item.title: Does ICE Need a Warrant to Enter Your Home?
item.description: Up until now, immigration officers were trained that they cannot enter homes without a judicial warrant. But, as our immigration reporter Hamed Aleaziz explains, the Trump administration has a different idea.
item.dc:creator: Hamed Aleaziz, Sutton Raphael, Rebecca Suner, June Kim and Whitney Shefte

item.title: Lawsuit Argues Trump Gold Card Visa Program Prioritizes Wealth Over Ability
item.description: The suit asks that a judge find the pay-for-play visa program unlawful, casting it as another example of the Trump administration’s seeking to bypass Congress.
item.dc:creator: Jonah E. Bromwich
item.media:credit: Tierney L. Cross/The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump and Secretary of State Marco Rubio are among the defendants named in a lawsuit that was filed on Tuesday.

item.title: William Stevenson, Jill Biden’s Ex-Husband, Is Accused of Killing His Current Wife
item.description: William Stevenson was arrested after being indicted on charges of first-degree murder in the death of his wife in December. He was married to Dr. Biden in the 1970s.
item.dc:creator: Billy Witz

item.title: Michael Parenti, Unapologetic Marxist Theorist and Author, Dies at 92
item.description: A prolific writer and lecturer, he viewed U.S. history through the lens of class struggle. But some accused him of defending brutal regimes in the Soviet Union and Serbia.
item.dc:creator: Trip Gabriel
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
Inventing Reality: The Politics of the Mass Media (Book)
item.media:credit: Herb Snitzer, via Michael Ochs Archive,/Getty Images
item.media:description: Michael Parenti in 1999. A feisty lecturer and critic of the mainstream media, he often took positions that few others on the American left would take.

item.title: Savannah Guthrie to Skip Olympics as Search for Mother, Nancy Guthrie, Yields Few Clues
item.description: The ‘Today’ anchor withdrew from NBC’s coverage of the Winter Games in Italy as investigators acknowledged they had few answers about who may have taken her mother, Nancy Guthrie, 84, from her home.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Holpuch, Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs and Reis Thebault
item.media:description: Savannah Guthrie, right, with her mother, Nancy, in 2019.

item.title: House Cancels Contempt Vote As Clintons Agree to Testify on Epstein
item.description: Bill and Hillary Clinton agreed to be deposed this month by an investigative panel but requested that it be in public, a request that the Republican chairman ignored.
item.dc:creator: Annie Karni
item.category: House Committee on Oversight and Government Reform
item.media:description: Former President Bill Clinton and former Senator Hillary Clinton at President Trump’s inauguration in 2025.

item.title: Trump Signs Bill to Reopen Government
item.description: The bill provides money for the Department of Homeland Security just through the end of next week, and the negotiations to curb immigration agents promise to be difficult.
item.dc:creator: Catie Edmondson
item.media:description: President Trump signing the spending package in the Oval Office on Tuesday.

item.title: Ruptures in China’s Leadership Could Be Due to Paranoia and Power Plays
item.description: U.S. intelligence analysts say that Xi Jinping, China’s leader, has a remarkable level of fear. He has carried out mass purges, and surprised many by removing his top general.
item.dc:creator: Edward Wong and Julian E. Barnes
item.media:description: Xi Jinping during a military parade in Tiananmen Square in Beijing last year.

item.title: Former Farming Leaders Warn U.S. Agriculture Could Face ‘Widespread Collapse’
item.description: A group of past government officials and the former heads of farming associations issued a dire warning to members of Congress.
item.dc:creator: Linda Qiu
item.media:credit: Kathryn Gamble for The New York Times
item.media:description: Corn being harvested on a family farm in Iowa in October.

item.title: Here’s the latest.
item.dc:creator: Mitch Smith, Michael Gold, Talya Minsberg and Claire Fahy

item.title: Polls Show Strong G.O.P. Support for Trump on Immigration
item.description: A small, but growing, share of Republicans say that enforcement has gone too far, after the killing of two Minneapolis protesters.
item.dc:creator: Ruth Igielnik
item.media:description: In Minneapolis, federal agents have prompted protests. A vast majority of Republicans still support President Trump’s aggressive immigration enforcement.

item.title: What to Know About the Disappearance of Savannah Guthrie’s Mom, Nancy
item.description: Nancy Guthrie, 84, the “Today” show host’s mother, was last seen on Saturday night, the authorities said. The disappearance is being investigated as a crime.
item.dc:creator: Claire Moses
item.media:description: Law enforcement officers outside the home of Nancy Guthrie near Tucson, Ariz., on Monday.

item.title: Investigation Finds Credit Suisse Had Wider Nazi Ties Than Previously Known
item.description: But a lawyer who has been scrutinizing archives and UBS are in a dispute over access to about 150 documents.
item.dc:creator: Charlie Savage
item.media:description: “Shining light on Credit Suisse’s past is part of turning the page, a very dark chapter of history,” said Senator Charles E. Grassley, the chairman of the Judiciary Committee.

item.title: Democrats Call on ICE Watchdog to Speed Up Use of Force Inquiry
item.description: The inspector general for the Department of Homeland Security is scrutinizing use of force by ICE, according to Democrats in Congress who requested the report.
item.dc:creator: Michael Gold

item.title: Colombian President Gustavo Petro Meets with Trump at the White House
item.description: Rather than further inflame tensions, the first in-person meeting between the two leaders yielded smiling photos and complimentary words, if no concrete agreements.
item.dc:creator: Annie Correal, Max Bearak and Minho Kim
item.media:description: Colombian President Gustavo Petro speaks at the Colombian Embassy in Washington after meeting with President Trump on Tuesday.

item.title: Pretti Shooting Thrusts Border Patrol’s History of Aggressive Tactics Into View
item.description: Officials have struggled to provide oversight of the agency, even as local communities and civil rights groups have documented episodes of violence.
item.dc:creator: Eileen Sullivan and Jazmine Ulloa
item.media:credit: Harry Pennington/Keystone Features, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Border Patrol officers detaining Mexican immigrants in Texas in 1948.

item.title: ‘They Couldn’t Break Me’: A Protester, the White House and a Doctored Photo
item.description: President Trump and the White House regularly circulate imagery that has been manipulated by A.I. But the photo of Nekima Levy Armstrong was different.
item.dc:creator: Erica L. Green
item.media:credit: Victor J. Blue for The New York Times
item.media:description: Nekima Levy Armstrong was arrested for protesting in St. Paul, Minn. She said she learned about the doctored photograph of her while she was in jail, during a phone call with her husband.

item.title: Colleges See Major Racial Shifts in Student Enrollment
item.description: An analysis finds that flagship state universities, as well as less selective colleges, had major increases in Black and Hispanic students following a ban on race-conscious admissions.
item.dc:creator: Stephanie Saul

item.title: In Trump’s Fraud Crackdown, Political Foes Face Harshest Scrutiny
item.description: State officials say the president’s actions are a new form of retribution, even as the White House has pardoned allies charged with defrauding government.
item.dc:creator: Tony Romm
item.media:credit: Allison Robbert for The New York Times
item.media:description: The president claims that his goal is to save taxpayers money, but some state officials say his actions are politically motivated and legally dubious.

item.title: Nick Shirley, the Influencer Who Spurred the Federal Crackdown in Minneapolis
item.description: Nick Shirley had struggled to expand his reach. With a new approach after a missionary trip, he caused a sensation with a video about possible fraud.
item.dc:creator: Ruth Graham
item.media:credit: Mark Abramson for The New York Times
item.media:description: Nick Shirley working on his next project, in San Diego.

item.title: San Francisco Mayor Daniel Lurie Focuses on Small City Changes Instead of Trump
item.description: Daniel Lurie has made small changes instead of addressing national tensions, and his approval ratings have been strong. It remains to be seen how long he can avoid the political fray.
item.dc:creator: Heather Knight and Cayce Clifford
